articles.headline: The U.S. Immigration System May Have Reached a Breaking Point
articles.snippet: For years, there have been warnings that America’s immigration system was going to fail. That time may be now.
articles.abstract: For years, there have been warnings that America’s immigration system was going to fail. That time may be now.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read the latest edition of Crossing the Border, a limited-run newsletter about life where the United States and Mexico meet. Sign up here to receive the next issue in your inbox.]
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Miriam Jordan and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: To Purge Some of Social Media’s Ugliness, an Unlikely Lesson From Wall St.
articles.snippet: A simple rule that bolsters the banking system — “know your customer” — could help combat fake news and hate speech online if companies like Facebook and Twitter embraced it.
articles.abstract: A simple rule that bolsters the banking system — “know your customer” — could help combat fake news and hate speech online if companies like Facebook and Twitter embraced it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exactly a year ago, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, testified before Congress and apologized for his company’s role in enabling “fake news, foreign interference in elections and hate speech.”

articles.headline: ‘China’s Manhattan’ Borrowed Heavily. The People Have Yet to Arrive.
articles.snippet: A largely empty urban district struggling with billions of dollars in debt demonstrates the breakdown of the Chinese economic growth model.
articles.abstract: A largely empty urban district struggling with billions of dollars in debt demonstrates the breakdown of the Chinese economic growth model.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — At a port in Germany, 150 Steinway pianos are waiting to be shipped to this gateway city for the grand opening of the Juilliard School’s second campus.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Uber Is Said to Aim for I.P.O. Valuation of Up to $100 Billion
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing giant gave some investors an initial estimate of its public market valuation, which ranged from $90 billion to $100 billion.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing giant gave some investors an initial estimate of its public market valuation, which ranged from $90 billion to $100 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber gave the first sign of how big its highly anticipated initial public offering might be, telling some investors that its stock sale might value it at up to $100 billion, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Barr Asserts Intelligence Agencies Spied on the Trump Campaign
articles.snippet: The attorney general said “spying did occur” in remarks certain to please President Trump, who has accused law enforcement officials of targeting his campaign.
articles.abstract: The attorney general said “spying did occur” in remarks certain to please President Trump, who has accused law enforcement officials of targeting his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr said on Wednesday that he would scrutinize the F.B.I.’s investigation of the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia, including whether “spying” conducted by American intelligence agencies on the campaign’s associates had been properly carried out.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: The National Enquirer Is for Sale, and a Deal Seems Near
articles.snippet: The hedge funders who control American Media Inc., the tabloid’s owner, are said to have grown uncomfortable after it was at the center of a federal investigation.
articles.abstract: The hedge funders who control American Media Inc., the tabloid’s owner, are said to have grown uncomfortable after it was at the center of a federal investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Enquirer, the supermarket tabloid that once published a photo of Elvis Presley in his coffin and later backed Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, is for sale, the publisher said in a statement.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Changes to Flight Software on 737 Max Escaped F.A.A. Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A new safety review wasn’t necessary under F.A.A. rules since the changes didn’t affect what the agency considers an especially critical or risky phase of flight.
articles.abstract: A new safety review wasn’t necessary under F.A.A. rules since the changes didn’t affect what the agency considers an especially critical or risky phase of flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: While designing its newest jet, Boeing decided to make two significant changes to an automated system now suspected of playing a role in two deadly crashes of the plane.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, David Gelles and James Glanz

articles.headline: Unsafe to Stay, Unable to Go: Half a Million Face Flooding Risk in Government Homes
articles.snippet: About 450,000 government-subsidized households are in flood plains, a threat that is growing more urgent in the era of climate change.
articles.abstract: About 450,000 government-subsidized households are in flood plains, a threat that is growing more urgent in the era of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a deadly rainstorm unloaded on Houston in 2016, Sharobin White’s apartment complex flooded in up to six feet of water. She sent her toddler and 6-year-old to safety on an air mattress, but her family lost nearly everything, including their car.

articles.headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Algorithms
articles.snippet: A racetrack veteran compares the Self Racing Cars contest in California to hot-rod modders of old: “This event, with its hackers, tinkerers and engineers, is just like that.”
articles.abstract: A racetrack veteran compares the Self Racing Cars contest in California to hot-rod modders of old: “This event, with its hackers, tinkerers and engineers, is just like that.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLOWS, Calif. — Faraz Khan’s all-electric Kia Soul is his workaday car, but on a drizzly weekend last month, he and his teammate, Jose Rojas, were hoping it would drive them to a racing milestone.
articles.byline: By Bradley Berman and Aaron Wojack

articles.headline: Under Modi, a Hindu Nationalist Surge Has Further Divided India
articles.snippet: The Hindu right has never been so enfranchised at every level of power. Now, with another term likely for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, minorities are worried.
articles.abstract: The Hindu right has never been so enfranchised at every level of power. Now, with another term likely for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, minorities are worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the machine tools market in the catacombs of Old Delhi, Muslims dominate the business stalls. But at night, they say, they are increasingly afraid to walk alone. And when they talk politics, their voices drop to a whisper.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Kai Schultz, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Julian Assange Arrested in London as U.S. Unseals Hacking Conspiracy Indictment
articles.snippet: Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, took refuge in 2012 in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London. He was arrested there on Thursday after Ecuador revoked his asylum status.
articles.abstract: Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, took refuge in 2012 in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London. He was arrested there on Thursday after Ecuador revoked his asylum status.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange was arrested on Thursday in London to face a charge in the United States of conspiring to hack into a Pentagon computer network in 2010, bringing to an abrupt end a seven-year saga in which he had holed up in Ecuador’s embassy in Britain to avoid capture.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Adam Goldman and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: The Fall of Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the ‘Spider’ at the Heart of Sudan’s Web
articles.snippet: Over 30 years, he forged a maze of security agencies and militias to bind his often ruthless rule. But he was undone in a middle-class revolt over the economy.
articles.abstract: Over 30 years, he forged a maze of security agencies and militias to bind his often ruthless rule. But he was undone in a middle-class revolt over the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir loved to tell the story about his broken tooth.

articles.headline: Ron Burkle, Billionaire Investor, Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy National Enquirer
articles.snippet: Mr. Burkle, a supermarket magnate with ties to President Bill Clinton, has emerged as a suitor for a tabloid linked to President Trump, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
articles.abstract: Mr. Burkle, a supermarket magnate with ties to President Bill Clinton, has emerged as a suitor for a tabloid linked to President Trump, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The owners of The National Enquirer have been in talks to sell the tabloid to Ronald W. Burkle, a supermarket magnate with ties to President Bill Clinton, according to three people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Andrew Ross Sorkin
